There is nothing much to bring a traveller to Port Klang except for the ferry links to

was history. Port Klang and Klang town is very popular as Food Haven for locals and dynamic entreprenuer business. The largest AEON shopping centre in Southeast Asia is operational in 2008 and the largest Wholesale city called

is projected to commence its wholesale business for products such as fashion apparels, all kinds of bags, ladies accessories, watches, building materials, electrical and electronic devices and more by the mid of 2009. Like most port cities, Port Klang has a seedy feel to it and most of its buildings and structures are maritime-related, such as warehouses, storage tanks and offices.

In maritime terms, Port Klang actually consists of three distinct ports. The port nearest to Port Klang town is known as the
located on an island just off the coast of Port Klang.
Port Klang lies at the western end of the
, the main expressway linking the major centres of the Klang Valley like

.

An elevated expressway linking the South Port (and hence Port Klang town) and North Port connects to the
The Port Klang bus and taxi terminal is inconveniently located about 1km inland from the port area. One can walk the distance but the heat, noise and pollution may make it an unpleasant experience.

value: , which belong to the same company, are the main buses serving Port Klang. No. 710 links Port Klang with Klang and Kuala Lumpur (Pasarama Kota or Klang Bus Stand) every half hour while No. 126 shuttles between Port Klang and Klang.
, also operate buses between Kuala Lumpur and Klang.

The railway station is located just outside the port area across the road from the ferry terminal.
, Klang Valley's commuter train network, links the station with
(one hour 10 minutes) with trains once every 15 minutes during peak hours, and once every 20 minutes during off-peak hours.

The ferry terminal - with the grand official name Passenger Cruise Terminal - is located in the port area where the Federal Highway (which is a two-lane city road at this point) meets the sea.

There are no domestic ferry services (except for boats to nearby

value: There are several operators and agents selling tickets at the terminal
-3167 1058). Departure times written on signboard at ticket counter, usually about 9am. RM100 one-way. Journey takes just under 3 hours.
MV Pelita Jaya Express/Sabang Marindo II
MV Boeing Sky King/Boeing Sky King II

While Dumai allows for visa on arrival,

value: Tanjung Balai Asahan does NOT issue visas on arrival

and travellers need a visa in advance. 

Malaysian citizens do not need a visa for a stay of up to 30 days and can enter at either port.

value: ships call at the Star Cruise Terminal at Westport...Costa Cruises use the Star Cruise Terminal. Taxis are available outside the terminal rates are quoted in Ringetts for single and return journeys

i.e Terminal to Port Klang City RM60 rtn. Terminal to KL including sightseeing RM240. Terminal to KL RM180. SCT to KL airport RM90 (as of 27 Oct2009). A taxi is required to reach the Port Klang train staion as well.
Walk to get from the ferry terminal to the railway station and bus and taxi terminal. Port Klang town just beyond the bus and taxi terminal and can also be reached on foot.
- in early May the area around the train station becomes a spectacle of Hindu devotion as pilgrims make their way under various painful burdens and chemical influences to the nearby

.

Unless you are here on shipping business, there is not a lot to do in Port Klang except to catch the ferry or to move on to

or other destinations.

Like in many other port cities, Hokkien is widely spoken here.
Most locals head out to the
area for good and relatively cheap (for the Klang Valley) seafood. Restaurants line the road and most are built on stilts over water. Other areas famous for seafood include

, both south of Port Klang.

The town of
, 8 km away, is famous for the pork rib soup
and worth a visit if in the vicinity.

value: content=217 Persiaran Raja Muda Musa. Popular business-class hotel (same management as the one in Petaling Jaya).

(Crab Island) is a mangrove covered island off the coast of Port Klang. The entire village is built on stilts and makes for an interesting day trip. About 15 ferries per day (RM7 one way, 45 min, the last boat from the island leaves at 5.30PM on weekdays and at 6PM on weekends and holidays) run from the Pulau Ketam jetty beside (and not inside) the Passenger Cruise Terminal. The island is popular at weekends as people from as far as
make the trip for good seafood.
